text: Hey everyone! I have signed countless contracts with agencies as a freelancer over the years, but one I'm looking at now has me a little stumped. 1) Do you currently include "prospective clients" in your non-solicitation clauses, and if so, how do you define this? Customers you've submitted a proposal to, etc? I would like a potential agency client to include a definition before I sign, so that I'm not locking myself out of work with anyone they've sent a direct mailer to, for example. 2) The contract states I will pay a percentage of earnings to this agency for any services performed in violation of this 18-month non-solicitation clause. I've seen this before, and it was never a problem, but this clause specifically states that the percentage is of _*the gross fees and other compensation received by me and any person or firm with which I am affiliated in connection with such client.*_  If I'm reading this right, not only would I have to pay a percentage of what *I make* as a freelancer if I violate this clause, but the percentage would be of the total project cost made by the agency that hires me. So I could be on the hook for x% of a $100,000 project, even if I only do a $400 blog post for them. Has anyone seen anything like this? If you own an agency, what wording would you recommend. Thanks.

So I could be on the hook for x% of a $100,000 project, even if I only do a $400 blog post for them. Has anyone seen anything like this? If you own an agency, what wording would you recommend. Thanks.

text: That’s excessive and mostly unnecessary. It’s worded for the worst case scenario where you take their client off to another agency. At minimum I’d ask for any specific prospective clients to be disclosed to you in order to qualify for part 1. And part 2 I’d ask to strike the rest of sentence after “received by me”.

elements.text: That’s excessive and mostly unnecessary. It’s worded for the worst case scenario where you take their client off to another agency. At minimum I’d ask for any specific prospective clients to be disclosed to you in order to qualify for part 1. And part 2 I’d ask to strike the rest of sentence after “received by me”.

text: Thank you, Kane. That was my feeling, as well, but wanted to be sure it wasn't some new trend that was happening. This is their standard client for many freelancers, and I'm wondering if most freelancers don't read, because it really stuck out to me.

elements.text: Thank you, Kane. That was my feeling, as well, but wanted to be sure it wasn't some new trend that was happening. This is their standard client for many freelancers, and I'm wondering if most freelancers don't read, because it really stuck out to me.

text:
Tbh… I own an agency, and I feel like prohibiting a freelancer from working with a prospective — not existing — client is _immense_ overkill bordering on inappropriate.

Not sure if you have budget for it, but I would consider running it by an attorney. My understanding is that asking a freelancer to sign a non-compete clause gets very tricky in terms of muddying the freelance vs. employee line — not to mention how bad it can be for you as the contractor. 

I'd be curious what the context is on that, and I love Kane’s advice above!

text: Appreciate your thoughts, <@U024K88ECFN>. It's good to hear that this isn't the norm in agency requirements. And yes, as a contractor who works with many agencies, this could limit my earning potential if not handled well. I'm going to run it by another person well versed in contracts, but wanted to get an idea of my spidey senses were in the right here. Thanks!
